description: From Middle English infesten, from Old French infester (“to infest”), from Latin īnfestō (“assail, molest”, verb), from īnfestus (“hostile”).

adjectives.description: infest (comparative more infest, superlative most infest)

examples: Did make an yrksome noyce to heare, as she her tresses shakes.
About her shoulders some did craule, some trayling downe her brest,
Did hisse, and spit out poison greene, and spirt with tongues infest.
Like as a fire, the which in hollow cave
Hath long bene underkept, and down supprest,
With murmurous disdayne doth inly rave,
And grudge, in so streight prison to be prest,
At last breakes forth with furious infest,
And strives to mount unto his native seat  […]

verbs.description: infest (third-person singular simple present infests, present participle infesting, simple past and past participle infested)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To inhabit a place in unpleasantly large numbers; to plague, harass.
(pathology, of a parasite) To invade a host plant or animal.
